Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In a partnership between the Omaha Public Schools (OPS) and the University of Nebraska at Omaha (UNO), this Noyce Scholarship Track Phase I program will address the national need for more underrepresented STEM talent who pursue careers in teaching. The initiative is building upon momentum from ongoing STEM Education initiatives at both institutions. The Omaha Noyce Partnership represents a new UNO initiative that aligns with NebraskaMATH, a statewide partnership that works to improve achievement in mathematics for all students and to narrow the STEM achievement gaps of at-risk populations. The Omaha Noyce Partnership will recruit a diverse pool of new teachers and provide much needed funding to support economically disadvantaged students. The partnership will strengthen and expand the pipeline for preparing mathematics teachers at UNO to better meet the high demand for teachers in local school districts, particularly in districts with high-need schools.

The Omaha Noyce Partnership scholarship program is designed to develop highly skilled secondary mathematics teachers who are committed to teaching in high-need schools by providing targeted support for students enrolled in and graduating from UNO's Bachelor of Science in Mathematics/Teacher Preparation program. The program includes new coursework and complements existing pathways that were developed by the UNO mathematics and education faculty in collaboration with school district partners. The project's evaluation activities will inform and advance ongoing collaborative research initiatives related to the effectiveness of inquiry-based learning in teaching mathematical concepts and in preparing students to be effective secondary mathematics teachers. All of the students supported by the Omaha Noyce Partnership will be enrolled in this new program and will receive focused training and extensive fieldwork in the Omaha Public Schools to prepare them for teaching careers in high need schools, including instruction in inquiry-based learning and other culturally responsive pedagogies.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Omaha Noyce Partnership program was designed to develop highly skilled secondary mathematics teachers who are committed to teaching in high need schools by providing targeted support for students enrolled in and graduating from the University of Nebraska at Omaha's (UNO) Bachelor of Science in Mathematics/Teacher Prep program. Our project objectives included providing structured internships to first- and second-year undergraduates (Noyce Interns), providing financial, academic, and professional development support for third- and fourth-year undergraduates (Noyce Scholars), and providing ongoing professional development support for former Noyce Scholars (Noyce Teachers). 

Project outcomes include:

  • Providing targeted support to 58 Noyce Interns between 2015-2020. Interns received bi-monthly mentoring, engaged in community outreach at local elementary, middle, and high schools, served as learning assistants in math and other STEM-focused secondary and post-secondary coursework, helped to facilitate a summer STEM program for underrepresented girls in Omaha, etc.
  • Providing targeted financial, academic, and professional support to 24 Noyce Scholars. Fourteen of these Noyce Scholars have graduated with their dual-degree and all of these Noyce Scholars continue to serve in high needs schools. Thirteen of the fourteen have remained in the Metropolitan Omaha-area. Five of the remaining ten Noyce Scholars are currently student teaching and are actively pursuing employment in the Omaha-area. Two other Noyce Scholars have not yet graduated and continue their coursework in mathematics and/or mathematics education. Throughout the project, only three Noyce Scholars were not retained as dual majors yet completed their mathematics majors, not seeking teaching credentials.
  • Providing continued engagement opportunities to Noyce Teachers through a) collaborative engagement in a city-wide Metropolitan Omaha Educational Consortium (MOEC) professional development series on professional learning communities, 2) ongoing listserv communication to provide just-in-time connections or resources, access to an online Facebook group to share ideas, successes, and/or challenges, 3) participation in recurring Noyce Teacher panels to share their experiences and ongoing learning experiences in the classroom, 4) access to professional books and literature to continue their growth as teacher leaders, and 5) ongoing professional development through monthly Math Teacher Circles.
  • Noyce Scholars, Interns, and Teachers annually have participated in several research projects annually, have presented at local, state, and national conferences, have developed curricular materials for community organizations and school districts, and have co-authored research papers with faculty mentors.

The Omaha Noyce Partnership, despite officially ending, will continue to have an impact on the student participants, future 7-12 students, and future UNO students going forward for years to come.  The Scholars and Interns in the program gained leadership and organizational skills through their weekly student meetings to organize outreach events, collectively participate in math education professional learning, and expand or deepen their mathematical knowledge by bringing a math problem to each meeting.  They will use those skills in their future employment. Future students at the high needs schools employing UNO Noyce Scholars will benefit from the impact of having highly qualified teachers in their classrooms. Future UNO students will benefit from the products of this Noyce Partnership, that has led to changes in students? coursework, program scope and sequence, and overall support mechanisms in place to recruit, engage and retain our Noyce Scholars and Interns.  Future pre-service teacher who are UNO students will benefit from the new and streamlined processes for community engagement (e.g., youth safety, professional outreach expectations), progress monitoring (e.g., weekly timesheets and reflection prompts), mentoring partnerships (e.g., strategic mentor/mentee pairings, Mentor Handbook), and formative and summative data collection to make program improvements and research that have been developed as part of this Noyce Partnership and standardized through the UNO?s STEM Teaching, Research, And Inquiry-based Learning (TRAIL) Center.
